inference:
The coordinates of the points are $Q(0, 12)$, $A(2, 12)$, $B(12, 0)$, and $C(0, p)$.
The base of $\triangle QCA$ is the segment $QA$ which is parallel to the x-axis. The length of $QA$ is $2$.
The height of $\triangle QCA$ is the perpendicular distance from $C$ to the line segment $QA$. Since $QA$ is horizontal, the height of $\triangle QCA$ is the y-coordinate of $C$, which is $p$.
The area of $\triangle QCA$ is given by $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height} = \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times p = p$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{p}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: Since $QA$ is perpendicular to $QC$, we can treat $QC$ as the height of $\triangle QCA$ and $QA$ as the base.  The area of $\triangle QCA$ is $$\frac{1}{2}\times QA\times QC=\frac{1}{2}\times(2-0)\times(12-p)=\frac{1}{2}\times2\times (12-p)=\boxed{12-p}.$$

ground_truth: Since $QA$ is perpendicular to $QC$, we can treat $QC$ as the height of $\triangle QCA$ and $QA$ as the base.  The area of $\triangle QCA$ is $$\frac{1}{2}\times QA\times QC=\frac{1}{2}\times(2-0)\times(12-p)=\frac{1}{2}\times2\times (12-p)=\boxed{12-p}.$$
